Award.AwardTitle: CI-P: Physical robotic manipulation test facility

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The robotics community has a rich history of research and development in teaching and training robots to pick up and manipulate objects. However, it has proven to be very difficult to transition this research from structured laboratory settings to real world settings, such as homes, small-scale industrial settings, and search and rescue domains. The development of large-scale, standardized testing and benchmarking of robotic manipulation approaches is necessary to move robotic manipulation from the research lab to the real world. Placing the burden of conducting these tests on every individual robotics researcher is inefficient, at best. Cleaning the captured data to make it available to other researchers requires additional work for the producers of the data - and even more work on potential users. All of this impedes progress for the community as a whole, and makes it difficult to bring to bear recent developments in deep learning. This project addresses this problem by setting the groundwork for a dedicated physical robotic grasping and manipulation testbed infrastructure that can be remotely accessed and operated by anyone doing research in this area.

This testbed will provide several critical components that the robotics grasping and manipulation community needs: (i) "Test suites" that enable repeated testing and controlled manipulation of several variables that have confounded robotic grasping and manipulation research. Variables include object and gripper material properties, compliance, force/torque of physical interaction, mass of manipulator elements and the objects, surface texture, low-level control algorithms, and higher-level planning techniques. (ii) Extensive instrumentation to capture (nearly) all aspects of the physical interaction, such as the forces, kinematics of movement, and three-dimensional geometry. (iii) A modular and customizable human-robot interface for enabling robotic physical interaction. Users will be able to directly control the robot using low-level interfaces, such as the knobs that control the movements of individual joints, or use higher-level interfaces that encapsulate robot-object interactions, such as close the fingers until they contact the object. (iv) Data collection, where the data will be made publicly available in a standardized form. The focus of this planning activity is to develop the necessary technological elements to prove the feasibility of such a test facility (automated object return in a fully instrumented space, a fully instrumented "door" to evaluate opening and closing doors) and to evaluate the community's needs in this area.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robotic grasping and manipulation is challenging, and very few methods exist for testing how well a specific system works in practice. This work produced three fully instrumented and automated testing objects (a door, a drawer, and a mechanism to return an object to the same pose for grasping tests) These devices, along with established procedures for performing the tests, will enable side-by-side comparisons of robotic grasping systems.

The door design has sensors to detect contact on the door handle, the pressure applied to the door handle, and the movement of the door. The door has multiple, swappable handle shapes along with a three-level setting for controlling how much force is needed to open the door.

The drawer design is similar to the door, but tracks how far the drawer has been opened.

The reset mechansim supports two types of resetting; either from the top or from the bottom. In either case, the final pose of the object can be adjusted by spinning the table top. There is a gantry for storing up to 10 objects, which can automatically be loaded into the testing mechanism. Altogether, the system supports automated grasp testing - the system automatically puts the object back in the same pose after the robot grabs and drops it.

For the grasp testing we also developed a set of canonical objects for the robot to grasp. Each object is instrumented with an inertial measurement unit, which enables tracking where the object went as it was moved.

Along with hardware, each device has a testing protocol that systematically checks the performance of the robotic system when the position of the object is varied slightly, representing the types of noise typically found in the real world. 

The majority of this work was conducted by undergraduates, through summer research experiences and senior design projects. This provided both educational opportunities (how to conduct rigorous experimental tests in robotics) and allowed students to use their knowledge in a creative way.

This work provides the backbone of an on-going project to enable remote robotic grasp testing, with one testing center located at the NERVE center at UMass Lowell, and the second at Oregon State University.


Last Modified: 01/07/2020
Modified by: Cindy Grimm

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Robotic grasping and manipulation is challenging, and very few methods exist for testing how well a specific system works in practice. This work produced three fully instrumented and automated testing objects (a door, a drawer, and a mechanism to return an object to the same pose for grasping tests) These devices, along with established procedures for performing the tests, will enable side-by-side comparisons of robotic grasping systems. The door design has sensors to detect contact on the door handle, the pressure applied to the door handle, and the movement of the door. The door has multiple, swappable handle shapes along with a three-level setting for controlling how much force is needed to open the door. The drawer design is similar to the door, but tracks how far the drawer has been opened. The reset mechansim supports two types of resetting; either from the top or from the bottom. In either case, the final pose of the object can be adjusted by spinning the table top. There is a gantry for storing up to 10 objects, which can automatically be loaded into the testing mechanism. Altogether, the system supports automated grasp testing - the system automatically puts the object back in the same pose after the robot grabs and drops it. For the grasp testing we also developed a set of canonical objects for the robot to grasp. Each object is instrumented with an inertial measurement unit, which enables tracking where the object went as it was moved. Along with hardware, each device has a testing protocol that systematically checks the performance of the robotic system when the position of the object is varied slightly, representing the types of noise typically found in the real world. The majority of this work was conducted by undergraduates, through summer research experiences and senior design projects. This provided both educational opportunities (how to conduct rigorous experimental tests in robotics) and allowed students to use their knowledge in a creative way. This work provides the backbone of an on-going project to enable remote robotic grasp testing, with one testing center located at the NERVE center at UMass Lowell, and the second at Oregon State University.
